Use your Debug tool/Oculus Tray tool. The default screen percentage (100) isn't equal to 1.0-pixel density, it's lower (0.76). Setting the screen percentage to 130=0.99-pixel density. 140=1.07-pixel density.

Specs: Ryzen R5 1600 (Stock), 16GB RAM @2667Mhz, GTX 1060 6GB OC'd to 2.1Ghz (Core) & 4.7Ghz (Memory).

Here are the best possible settings for my config with 0 frame drops:
Post Process Quality: 4
Shadow Quality: 2
Texture Quality: 4
Effects Quality: 4
Screen Percentage: 180 (1.34-pixel density)
Anti-Aliasing: 0
If you're dropping frames, try a Screen Percentage of 150 (1.13).

I prefer Post-Precessing be set to "2" as "3" or above creates a bloom like an effect around all light sources. Settings Shadow Quality to "1" removes all shadows and breaks immersion (for me at least). Setting this to "3" or above increases the resolution at which shadows will be rendered. Whether I set Textures/Effects Quality to "1" or "4" I couldn't tell a difference but for peace of mind, I left them at 4 as I saw little to no performance hit. Unless you're playing with a screen percentage set to 270 (2.01-pixel density) or higher PLEASE, leave Anti-Aliasing set to 0, otherwise, set it to 1. It's not MSAA or SMAA. It's more like FXAA and TSAA had a baby. It blurs your entire image and reduces the overall brightness of objects.

But, if you're like me and ASW doesn't bother you (or you disable it entirely) these settings will have the game looking it's best (for my hardware's sake) without running like complete sh*t.

Settings: (ASW Will Be Enabled 90% Of The Time)
Post Process Quality: 2
Shadow Quality: 2
Texture Quality: 4
Effects Quality: 4
Screen Percentage: 250 (1.90-pixel density) Everything's clear!
Anti-Aliasing: 0

I've played a couple small 'flying sims/flying experiences' on rift before, this has been the most compelling of any of them.

The environment, a combination of your cockpit, the city, the rain, and the music - are all really cool. I just loved existing in this world with them. When I started the game, I got vertigo looking out the windows of the cockpit, but the cockpit felt real enough that I was safe. I *pretended* to punch buttons and make beep and click noises for them to 'adjust things', since you don't presently have 'hands' in the game, even with touch. 
Oh, and when you are near enough to a landing site you hear indistinct radio voices implying like landing control or similar.
This game seems to know how much to imply and how much to actually include to create a really fun universe that I want more of.

The controls are simple and effective. The UI in the cockpit is interesting, and readable. There are places to find and 'land' to get powerups and that's so much more effective and compelling than I expected.

I found myself dodging and weaving through the traffic for fun. I flew so far out of bounds that the game *teleported me back to spawn* (or maybe it thought I'd died) becaused I just wanted to see if there would be a landing pad on one of the radio antennae that I initially thought were part of the *skybox*

I would love an expanded sandbox on this concept - just a few mission-givers for delivery/pickup maybe to add flavour. You could give players hints rather than gps 'markers' to encourage them to explore the city and/or find their own routes.

I'd also love the ability to use touch control *as* touch control, even if pushing the buttons in the cockpit had *no* functionality and made cool beep noises.

review_title: A Must-Try Tech Demo for VR
one_reviews_text:
This was already one of the first experiences I'd let folks try out when demoing my Rift (with one caveat: it's NOT for people who get VR sickness).  Piloting a flying car around the rainy future city is incredibly immersive.  Now it's been updated with a lick of polish - vertical flight controls, some extra neon signs and holographic sculptures, plus a handful of detailed landing pads to find (and upgrade your boost meter) to give the experience some hint of a goal.  Not that it's necessary - this is clearly in the "tech demo" realm rather than anything resembling a full game, but it's a pleasure just to tool around checking out every corner of the little city in your flying car.
As I said, be warned that the 6 degrees of freedom afforded by the contols allow for a highly immersive experience, but can easily induce VR sickness in individuals who are susceptible to it.

one_reviews_text:

- Controls work like they should and how you would expect of a flight sim.

I love this free experience. I keep coming back to it. I love the relaxing atmosphere, the sights and sounds, the Aircar's controls are intuitive. In some ways, I wish the game had a larger map with a mode  for achieving specific objectives, but in others ways, I love just jumping in and piloting the aircar as I wander free around the city.

So I thought I had a stomach of steel until I played this.  Free movement, looking around ,etc. doesn't bother me but this game has a sick factor of 11 for me, strange.

Still, great experience -- very immersive cockpit and good graphics (I have a 1080GTX  -- I use the Oculus debugger to render at 2.0 and then turn shadows down in game for a great graphical and smooth exprience).

Nothing much to do, but it's nice flying around.  Oh, if you're like me and you get sick playing this, tip:  *DO NOT* lean one way with your body while tilting another way with the ship.  Puke factor increases 10x.

Instead, lead sideways when you turn sideways, look forward/down when you dive, lean back/up when you climb, and twist in your chair when you yaw (helps to have a swivel desk chair for all this).  If you follow that, sick factor is very low but on my first play I didn't and boy I'm still paying for it 10 minutes later (woozy but no barfing)!  Have fun, good little demo.

If you could incorporate something like this into a game like Deus Ex, with parts where you walk around the city and parts where you fly to different areas and can enter/exit the craft would be amazing. Only a cyberpunk RPG or action game would really do this justice, not purely a flying sim. Oh its just wishful thinking I know, no company would pour those resources into a VR game this early in the lifecycle with the small userbase. A man could dream.

Anyone who has played any Deus Ex game might understand, the flying sections are just cut scenes. If this was the flying scene, with actual monitoring of surroundings and scanning the ground for crimes or points of interest (the panel on the dash to the left would be perfect) this would become an instant classic.

I thought i would give this a go as it was free, and i'm really...really happy that i did. Though can't quite believe i didn't need to pay anything for this experience, and experience is what this is. It's like this, you fly your future space car 
which feels a bit like a helicopter (a really really bloomin awesome future space type of helicopter) seriously some people have said the graphics in this demo aren't up to par, i beg to differ, this is the most presence i have had in any flight sim, bump the graphics up to high and you are as close as your going to get to flying around in blade runner. Anywho, you fly your future car around a futuristic city...........i know, it sounds boring, but it's really not, it's soooo good. If this ever becomes a full fledged game you can take my money. Well done to the devs as this is a master class in what VR can be. Seriously folks you should download this right now, though be prepared to lose a fair few hours doing high risk acrobatics while feeling like a total boss :)

review_title: Fly high, fall down and .... crash
one_reviews_text:
I bought games worth a total of 100€.
And I play a game, which is for free.

I played games with elaborated game mechanics.
But nothing amazed me more than a game, which mechanic only includes the spaceship I fly  and a few ugly NPC spaceships.

I drove like a madman through Sweden, Germany or Greece in Dirt Rally.
But I felt never more alive (in a game), when I looked calmly at the city from above, planing my way through the city, knowing I will crash. 

Maybe I wouldn't crash that often, if I whould fly slowlier. Yeah... Whould....
You won't regret it , it's the best sci-fi exploration game there is , and it's free !

This completely blew my mind. I knew before hand that the app wouldnt have many features. But oh boy does it utilise everything it was well. I felt so immersed in my little ship that shrap turns owuld often make me motion sick only to stop and take a break would leave me feeling refreshed as I took a arial view at the city and surrondings. Everything from the lighting to the smooth ship momovement added to the experience.  Even the nice sequence at the end where you run out of fuel. Won't spoil it, but its quite nice and refreshing from a game haha. 

Would recommend to absolutely everyone!
The first thing I tried with my new rift and for a simple sim with no story, objectives or anything else I know I will keep coming back to this one! So much fun and well executed!
ill from physics

review_title: This is a great demo/proof of concept
one_reviews_text: This is my go to demo for introducing new users to the Rift. Not a game but very fun to fly around and listen to your own music. Does a good job at allowing you to test your rig with different graphics settings. The rain and cockpit design do a good job at creating immersion while minimizing VR sickness. Because it's free, 4 stars.

review_title: gorgeous. Please make a full game!!!
one_reviews_text: Must experience! This was like living in a sci-fi movie based in the distant future!

Actually this didn't have as bad of an affect on my stomach as some other VR titles - ones that don't even involve flight.  However, it is just an, "Experience," meaning that there isn't much to do other than pilot the aircar around.

For what it is, it is good, but if VR is to grow - well, we need more than, "Experiences."

The atmosphere is spot on. The music is gorgeous. The cityscape is hypnotic.
An absolute masterpiece.

Overall this presents a visually beautiful futuristic nightime urban environment and an excellent control scheme in an airborne vehicle that I hope to experience in the real world some day (hello Tesla?).  

However (spoiler alert); navigating the air car from high to low altitude and around sharp turns was truly a visceral gut-rench.  I think I have a high tolerance for most queasy VR experiences.  It took fortitude to stick it out for about 30 minutes to get a real orchestrated hand of the joysticks, but then I sought in vain for a purpose beyond just managing my own gut reaction.  Keep a basin nearby just in case.

Really, really awesome! Full controls for flying around a sci-fi big city environment with crowded areas aswell as abandoned outskirts.

Like Timimimi (the reviewer before me), I really wish the developers will make something more from this. Simple passanger missions would totally do! Like the oldschool games were you'd pick up passangers from one platform and give them a ride to another platform.

Simple basics, but it would add so much! A the moment there's not much to do but to explore the surroundings, but even so the experience is amazing!

If I must say something "negative" it's that I wish you could strafe up and down...but hey, its free so maybe I should just shut up and fly already :)

Beautiful demo!)
But it's too slow :(

I give this game an achievement: It's the first thing I've played on my Oculus that legitimately made me feel sick. I've played a number of others, but never did I experience any motion sickness until this one. The graphics feel a little underdeveloped, especially if you fly close to t he ground. The cars near street level are just simple planes with graphcs on top.

review_title: I hope this is just the beginning
one_reviews_text:
I find this demo very soothing. You can fly any way you like. Graphics are very nice and you can adjust settings if neccesary. 
I really hope this is just the base of something bigger since I really enjoyed flying around. Also love the attention to details with the buttons. It would be awesome if you really could toggle these. 
One thing I noticed was that the steeringwheel and compass started to drift away. 
And too bad there aren't any tow trucks, but yes...I do love staring at the moon ;-)

This is a very well made VR demo. It is also a very relaxing environment to spend some time in. You fly an air car a la Blade Runner, and the environment is also very much reminiscent of that movie. Rain drops dance on your windscreens as you fly around, and even respond to air rushing over them as you increase your speed. I find myself going back for more on a regular basis, it's my current form of relaxation and I even use it for meditation. Thank you so much for making this!
Epic exp.,....GOOD JOB

-Nice feeling to fly in VR
-Big Map

Con:

Fantastic!

Amazing experience... really, really convincing. Not for the faint of stomach, but man... really thrilling ride. I worked up to doing some loops and rolls, and those just about did me in. Felt like a real pilot though, totally worth it!

review_title: Best VR in a long time!
one_reviews_text: The developers really need to take this one to the next level. Make a game or a multiplayer sim. I really had a lot of plain ole fun with this VR sim. Would be pretty cool to have a gas station we could refuel at. Would also be cool to have buildings to fly through or a sort of maze of buildings to try and fly through.

I'm hard to impress when it comes to VR, especially when it just comes to experiences. This has to be by far one of the nicest feeling VR experiences i've ever had. The craft is so easy to control and there is so much that could be done with the experience to improve it.

the game is great, and you really feel like you are inside the game, but i would recommend this game if you are planning to go into space and you need to test your stomach for motion sickness, i have played several strong games, like project cars, but this one I had to fight the sickness bad, I was able to play it for a good 15 minutes before I could not stand it anymore, but other than that a good VR experience,my only complaint is that the Oculus and any other modern VR suffers from long distance resolution issues, when the computers are powerfull enough to run 4k on each eye at 90 fps then VR is going to be the real thing, up until then everything far looks pixelated.

Ok - so admittedly there isn't really a game here per se, but if you ever wanted to play out your Bladerunner flying-car fantasies, this is the app for you. It's great for just chilling out in and flying around, brilliantly immersive, I would love to see the devs take this further.

review_title: Makes a case for why VR is so incredible
one_reviews_text:
I started with the Oculus Dreamdeck and First Contact, and they were incredible, but when I fired up Aircar, that's when it really clicked and became overwhelming in how amazing VR really is.  Aircar is a fantastic demonstration for anyone just starting out in VR and done the tutorial demos but want something to take it to the next level in awesome.

Would love to see this app expanded with some more features;  a bigger city or an additional one, the ability to go underwater, some interactivity with the touch controller inside the cockpit, etc.

review_title: This is what VR is about!

one_reviews_text:
We are at the top here. This is, hands off, the best tech demo that vr as to offer.
It's all what i want from vr experience, the mood, the freedome, the immersivity, it's all here. Only one thing i would have appreciate more, a smaller ship, other than that is an astonishing trip. I would instatly buy a game from this guys.

Good Vr sim.  One huge, glaring hole in the controls though.  There is no ability to control altitude except via pitch and thrust.  I would have love to have landed on a building but with no Increase/Decrease Altitude control this was very difficult.  Also it would be nice to see the aircar from the outside (external view).
So much fun ! I could fly around for ages and the music fits perfectly.

Very nice simulation, i feel the controls should be more based on grabbing a virtual steering wheel and pressing virtual buttons in the cockpit rather than just pressing them on the controller, but the actual experience is great, quite intense though, i can imagine many people getting VR sickness from it

Ummm what do i say... exactly the kind of game i was looking for I would definetly buy a the game if it came out with an large open world pack the only thing bad with it for me was holy sh*t did i get motion sickness badly but other than that fantastic game :)

Better than a lot of paid for games out there.  This is a lovely VR experience.  If you ever watnted to drive one of those Blade Runner cars... this is the closest you are going to get for the time being.  Thank you Giantform.  I look forward to your next creation.

One of the best relaxing experiences out there. Like chilling in BladeRunner airspace.

Only 1 complaint but doesn't detract from 5 stars. Controls would be best to be configurable. Mode 1 & 2 like RC aircraft/helicopters. Current control scheme is not very intuitive.
This little experience is really REALLY fun!  The mood, the music, the controls, the graphics, everything just came together really well. Great job to the developers!!!

review_title: If only it were a full game
one_reviews_text: This little demo here is something else. I actually got kinda disoriented even through i play games like DCS World and Elite Dangerous and yet somehow this one actually gets me pretty good. Putting that aside, The level of detail in this little demo is amazing. I felt like i was flying around like some kinda cop in a futuristic city, You know, it made me think of the movie Bladerunner, the original movie and this is actually free? Yeah it's worth downloading. Lol, i couldnt stay upside down for long or id get that woosy feeling, smh that just usually doesn't happen to me :P

This is incredible for a free game! I so so wish they create a full game of this. New ships or what not. Maybe just make it basic. It is called Aircar... So maybe we can fly our ships around and pick passangers up! That could be cool and its basic but fun!
I only wish there was more to explore but it's still well worth the download.  I had a blast; now just integrate a ship like this into Google Earth!

A really nice experience for being able to fly around a cityscape in the rain. There's nothing really beyond that but it shows what could happen with future developments.

I definitely got a bit motion sick whilst playing this though, so do be wary with this one and try not to play it for too long. I suggest sitting down.
Love it, amazing experiance. Feel sick after a while though.

This is a beautiful and relaxing game set in an amazing sci-fi environment. But just a warning, all three people I had try this game (including myself) ended up nauseus for the rest of the day. If you try it, try it in short spurts.

Once you get used to controlling your ship and can do loops etc. without getting nauseated - it's a great experience. I like the atmosphere. So far the best game I've played even though it has no particular purpose other then to fly around.
great experience, sure it's worth a download

This is less of a game, and more of a place to just kick back and admire the scenary. It's a preview and a hint at the sort of amazing experiences and worlds we'll one day be able to explore and live in thanks to VR, but for now, it's sadly paper thin. Definitely a great demo to show off to your family and friends how immersive VR can be though.

Super experience! Good visuals, immersive, GREAT controls.

It's light years better than the Bladerunner VR tie in promo snoozefest that probably had a much bigger budget.

review_title: A Must Have (Helps that it's Free)
one_reviews_text: Still, I understand why you might be hesitant to install even a free game.  They tend to clog up the library.  Rest assured, this one is worth it.  I find myself loading it up all the time to just fly...relax...listen to the music...watch the rain fall.  I'm not sure what the developers intended with this, or what they intend down the road, but for a relaxing fly around a futuristic city to some pretty chill music, this is an absolute must.

I wondered if being in a vehicle made moving in VR while stationary less puke inducing and this seems to be the case. This is more comfortable than Google Earth VR's free flight, so that gives me great hope for driving games. If you are anticipating your movements it's not bad but if the controls get away from you it gets disorienting. Amazing detail for a free game.
Amazing experience!

Absolutely stunning. Very Blade Runner-y. I would've loved to fly around for longer than a few minutes just to be able to look around more. Unfortunately I have never gotten motion sickness so fast in my entire life.
I tried a lot of games and experiences in VR, but for me Aircar is just the best I have experienced so far !!!

This is a fun and relaxing experience. I hope they add more to this, but definitely nothing to complain about since it's free! 

Add touch controls and I'd pay money for something like this.
Own quite  a few games now and keep goin back to this . You fly a ship around a small city bladerunner style...no guns , no enemies ...just fly
A must try for anyone interested in aviation,pitch,roll,yaw piloting & its set in a great sci fi universe. Want more!!!

review_title: -= Please make this into a game ! =-
one_reviews_text:
It is certainly no coincidence that this flight simulator carries the title "Air Car". The references to Ridley Scott's cult classic BLADE RUNNER can also be found in alot of design decisions and also the soundtrack creates a similar atmosphere. In terms of graphics I am only missing dynamic lighting, some density like fog and smog or floating particles in the air. The cockpit is beautifully designed and has that lovely retro sci-fi touch to it. I also love the raindrops on the windshield, but it's a pity that no actual rain is simulated. This would make the simulation so much more convincing. For that the controls of the car feel surprisingly convincing and are easy to learn. Even the slight motion sickness you can experience by flying extreme maneuvers makes the simulation even more realistic. For now it is just cruising around exploring the dystopian city wich is amazing for a free simulator. But imagine beeing chased or chasing others or just having an actual goal to achieve. This is why I could not give a 5 star rating as this software is more of a showcase for something bigger.

I mean you could place billboards in the game to finance further development and it would even benefit the design giving the city a breath of life and this title could stay free to play and still be profitable.

This piece of software has so much potential! I would love to see this title involve into a game with some depth and purpose.
the game is free so you are not paying for anything. Great flying car simulator. If  rated COMFORT level would be INTENSE.
Really cool! Ofc it's not a final product, but this demo clearly declared, that such game can be "must buy" product!

enjoyed my time wizzing in and out of buildings

If this could somehow be translated into a game, then I would be intriged (but it would surprise me if that would be really possible, without being too repetitive)

It shows you that if there was a game with more fidelity and gameplay mechanics, a game like this could really suck you in.

review_title: Although very beautifull it is boring.

Nice to amaze friends with who have never seen VR or if you are new to VR. For people who have seen the VR game or two allready there's a better way to waste your time on.
Just WOW!!! best experience so far, you should definetly make a game on this.

I am an Oculus owner and used the Touch Controllers.  I really enjoyed the excellent graphics.  I felt like I was really in the cockpit sitting here in my chair. I didn't see any tutorial, so it took me a little bit to figure out which buttons did what.  Flying around slow and easy was great, but when I got agressive with my maneuvers I got motion sick pretty quickly.  For what this demo is, it is excellent! This made me airsick for the first time in my life. I say this with good humor but it's true none the less. I hold a commercial and Instrument flying license.  This game accomplished what my years of training couldn’t, it gave me spatial disorientation to a degree I had to set the simulation down on the street, (I’m a professional, couldn’t just pull the plug), and go lay down and couldn’t eat for several hours.  The fact it could make me sick is actually a good thing, because it means it comes close to the real sensations of flight. The game will not attract players if they become ill. Here’s my advice.  The Xbox controller configuration is opposite of what MS Flight simulator or Lockheed Martin’s Prepar3D uses. The pitch and bank should be on the left stick and yaw on the right.  Being able to reconfigure the controls to fly in a familiar manner should be part of the settings.  Giving the player some things to focus on will also help, I suggest a better horizontal situation indicator on the center control panel. This gives the eye something to reference while flying and helps prevent nausea. Tactile vibration feedback on the controller also helps.  I hope to return to play the simulator, just not with a full stomach.

review_title: Everything about this game is great
one_reviews_text: You will feel like a taxi driver in the movie the 5th element. The controls are great (even if there is no real oculus touch support). The music is relaxing. Even with all its simplicity, I like it better than Eagle Flight and UltraWings (which are great games as well).

I have a thing for cozy cockpit interiors, moody weather, cyberpunk cityscapes, and down-tempo music played over radio chatter. Basically, I feel like the demo was made for me and I almost fell asleep a couple of times from just how cozy it was.

My only complaint is that there isn't a bed in the interior to lay down in. There's also an amusing little thing if you let the car run out of fuel. There's no reason not to check this out.

For what it is (a free *concept* demo) it was great.  Obviously there are bugs that will be fixed if development continues (the controls like to move into the dashboard) and it's a relatively small world that actually has 3d buildings (but they look great, I found myself flying around looking in windows even though they are just 2d textures slapped on awesome 3d buildings), and it really needs an "up/down" option on the left stick (essentially thrusters pointed straight down and straight up, so your relative facing is unchanged) and like elite dangerous, for those long drives you really need the ability to project youtube/netflix into the cockpit (don't tell the highway cops).  

But I spent over 30 minutes just flying around and it's moved to the top of my list of things to show friends to demo VR. Looks great.  [Also the speed indicator is probably about 10 times your actual speed, those rain drops are not moving 150 mph]. 

But an amazing initial framework.

Super relaxing, the cars movement is responsive and well executed, and the music is perfect. 

Found a few bugs; [REDACTED: Looks like the steering wheel drift bug has been fixed ;) ] I've also had the yaw control lock up in a permanent turn, and boosting seems to reset it. I'm sure these'll get ironed out in the future though.

By the way, easter egg if you run out of fuel ;)
